paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses two variants of the TTR gene: T119M and S52P, detailing their clinical significance, penetrance data, and functional effects.

patients.phenotype: asymptomatic of FAP or present a more benign form of the disease

individual_records.evidence_sentence: The T119M mutation is non-amyloidogenic, and heterozygous individuals carrying the T119M mutation and an amyloidogenic mutation, such as V30M, either remain asymptomatic of FAP or present a more benign form of the disease.

functional_data.summary: The T119M mutation stabilizes the dimer–dimer interface as well as TTR’s tertiary structure.

variants.segregation_data: The T119M mutation is associated with a protective effect against FAP.
variants.additional_notes: The T119M mutation is noted for its protective effects against amyloidosis.
key_quotes: The T119M mutation is non-amyloidogenic, and heterozygous individuals carrying the T119M mutation and an amyloidogenic mutation, such as V30M, either remain asymptomatic of FAP or present a more benign form of the disease.

individual_records.evidence_sentence: On the other hand, individuals carrying the S52P mutation develop aggressive and early-onset fatal amyloidosis.

functional_data.summary: The S52P mutation destabilizes TTR by altering the stability of the CD loop in the protein monomer.

variants.segregation_data: The S52P mutation is associated with familial amyloid polyneuropathy.
variants.additional_notes: The S52P mutation is highly amyloidogenic and leads to severe disease manifestations.
key_quotes: On the other hand, individuals carrying the S52P mutation develop aggressive and early-onset fatal amyloidosis.

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data was extracted from the main text.
